docs.lead_paragraph: NOW that the Internet's young, high-spending set is increasingly sharing cyperspace with older, less affluent users, some significant electronic commerce opportunities are emerging. Consider drug retailing. As online users look to reduce their prescription costs and the number of trips to the drugstore, analysts say Web pharmacists are well positioned to take a greater share of the retail pharmaceutical market.

headline.main: E-Commerce Report; As baby boomers grow older, online prescription drug sales are showing steady growth.

docs.abstract: Online sales of prescription drugs show steady growth as Internet users seek to cut costs and frequency of trips to drugstores; pharmacy-benefit management plans, which help run benefits programs for health insurers, are in strongest position to capitalize on online drug sales; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bloomberg Gets Deal to Expand Smoking Curbs'' (front page, Dec. 12): In the debate surrounding the smoke-free workplaces bill, some hard facts concerning the effect on businesses have gotten lost.

headline.main: Breathe Deeply and Enjoy a Beer

docs.abstract: Annie Beigel letter points out that if fewer people smoke, health cost increases will modify, benefiting all businesses and nonsmoking individuals

docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE play chicken with their health insurance all the time. They leave their jobs and their employer-sponsored health plans, gambling that they won't be in an accident or become seriously ill before they get another job that has a group plan. Once secure in their new positions, they may think their insurance worries are over. But that's not necessarily the case. A gap in coverage, even for just a few months, could leave people responsible for certain medical bills for up to a year.

headline.main: When Health Coverage Is Decided by the Calendar

docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews column warns that people who allow gap in their health coverage of only a few months can wind up responsible for certain medical bills for up to a year; notes that Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 safeguards coverage for pre-existing medical conditions after worker joins employer's group health plan only if there has been no significant break in coverage; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Retirees will soon have to pay more to cover health care costs, a recent study of large employers suggests. Eighty-two percent of the 435 companies in the survey said they planned to increase health insurance premiums paid by retirees over the next three years, and 85 percent said they planned to raise prescription drug co-payments.
docs.abstract: Survey of 435 companies finds that 82 percent plan to increase health insurance premiums paid by retirees over next three years and that 85 percent plan to raise prescripion drug co-payments; nearly all say they will continue offering health insurance to current retirees in next three years, but 22 percent say they are likely to eliminate health coverage for future retirees within three years (M)
docs.snippet: Retirees will soon have to pay more to cover health care costs, a recent study of large employers suggests.    Eighty-two percent of the 435 companies in the survey said they planned to increase health insurance premiums paid by retirees over the...

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey business owners expect a 14 percent increase in health insurance costs in 2003, according to an annual survey released last week by Mercer Human Resource Consulting, an international consulting organization that studies business issues. Health insurance costs in New Jersey, which are higher than the national average, rose 9.2 percent this year to an average of $6,021 per employee. Nationally, rates increased 14.7 percent this year to an average of $5,696 -- the largest increase since 1990. Small employers providing health insurance fell from 66 percent in 2001 to 62 percent this year. Among large employers, those with more than 500 workers, the drop was 1 percent, to 87 percent. Karen DeMasters
docs.abstract: Mercer Human Resource Consulting releases annual survey showing that health insurance costs in New Jersey rose 9.2 percent in 2002, to average of $6,021 per employee; reports business owners expect 14 percent increase 2003 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mardi Gras in Cadiz Q. What can you tell me about visiting Cadiz at Mardi Gras? We've been told it's a major event.-- Rhoda Peterson, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. A. Mardi Gras is the culmination of pre-Lenten Carnaval, one of the most dazzling events of the year in Spain and one of the largest such celebrations in the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In criticizing taxes, Mr. Feldstein says they cause people to spend large sums on housing and to put unnaturally high value on company benefits because of the tax advantages they offer. Indeed, these tax breaks encourage individual home ownership and company retirement and medical plans because these are considered essential to American well-being. Tax incentives also allow people to get these things through the private sector, relieving government of the burden of providing them. Paternalistic? A bit. Good government? Absolutely.

headline.main: A Harvard Professor And Economic Policy

docs.abstract: Robert Wyman letter comments on Dec 1 article on Martin Feldstein, regarding his views on how taxes determine value people put on housing and company benefits; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a young woman, Joan Cain never dreamed that she would go to Antarctica, Alaska and Russia -- much less all three in one year. ''I only started traveling about 10 years ago,'' she said recently, now 59, a paralegal and living in Atlanta. She is planning to take all three trips with the adventure company ElderTreks in 2003. ''After my husband died I discovered that traveling was my passion,'' said Ms. Cain. Mature travelers -- usually defined as 50 or 55 and over -- are the fastest-growing group of consumers in the industry. Dozens of tour companies now cater exclusively to older travelers, promising greater attention to health and mobility concerns, as well emphasizing stress-free travel and comfortable accommodations.
docs.abstract: Susan Catto Practical Traveler column on travel tips for mature travelers--those 50 or 55 and over--fastest-growing group of consumers in travel industry; descriptions of travel agencies and tour operators that cater to mature travelers; drawing (M)
